METASCHEMA.schema-name: OSCAL Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) Format

remarks.p: The OSCAL Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) format is used to describe the information typically provided by an assessor during the preparation for an assessment.
The root of the OSCAL Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) format is plan-action-milestones.

define-assembly.name: metadata
define-assembly.description: Provides information about the publication and availability of the containing document.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: prop field ...

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Used to provide a listing of keywords. This is typically used on a prop in the metadata to provide keywords for the document.

define-assembly.name: responsible-party
define-assembly.description: A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role relative to the parent context.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: The role that the party is responsible for.

allowed-values.enum: Indicates the organization that created this content.
Indicates the organization for which this content was created.
Indicates the organization responsible for all content represented in the "document".

define-assembly.name: back-matter
define-assembly.description: A collection of citations and resource references.

remarks.p: Provides a collection of identified citation and resource objects that can be referenced by a link with a rel value of "reference" and an href value that is a fragment "#" followed by a reference to a citation identifier. A citation can reference a resource by specifying a local target value using the same fragment-identifier approach.

example.description: Use of link, citation, and resource

remarks.p: The following is a contrived example to show the use of link, citation, and resource.

define-assembly.name: revision
define-assembly.description: An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document in reverse chronological order (i.e., most recent previous revision first).

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: link field ...

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: rel flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Indicates that the href points to the source resource for the revision entry.

remarks.p: While published, last-modified, oscal-version, and version are not required, values for these entries should be provided if the information is known. For a revision entry to be considered valid, at least one of the following items must be provided: published, last-modified, version, or link.

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: A reference to a local or remote resource

remarks.p: This is a rough analog to an HTML anchor (a), except this is a line-oriented (block) element.

The href must point to a local or remote resource. If a local resource is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified citation or resource in the document's back-matter. If a remote resource is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced resource. A relative URI can be resolved relative to the location of the document containing the link.
To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to a resource is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the rlink hash object.
The media-type provides a hint about the content model of the referenced resource. A valid entry from the IANA Media Types registry
The following is a contrived example to show the use of link, citation, and resource.

define-field.name: published
define-field.description: The date and time this document was published.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was published. The date value must be an ISO 8601 formatted date with full time and time zone indicated. Ordinarily, a date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the last-modified-date value should indicate the modification time of the OSCAL document, not the source material. (The nominal publication date of the original source material can be captured as a named property or custom metadata construct.)

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its sibling last-modified to establish commonality across OSCAL instances that are intended to be considered as successive current versions of a given publication.

define-field.name: last-modified
define-field.description: Date and time of last modification.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was last updated. The date value must be an ISO 8601 formatted date with full time and time zone indicated. Ordinarily, a date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the last-modified value should indicate the modification time of the OSCAL document, not the source material.

define-field.name: version
define-field.description: The version of the document content.

remarks.p: A string indicating the document's version, by release number, date, or other identifier. This version is typically set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.

define-field.name: oscal-version
define-field.description: OSCAL model version.

remarks.p: Indicates the version of the OSCAL model to which this data set conforms, for example 1.0-M1.

define-field.name: doc-id
define-field.description: A document identifier qualified by an identifier type.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Qualifies the kind of document identifier.

allowed-values.enum: A Digital Object Identifier (DOI); use is preferred, since this allows for retrieval of a full bibliographic record.

remarks.p: A document identifier or name, qualified by a type that indicates the naming system of the identifier. A document identifier may provide a hint to the persistent location of the same or another version of the document.
Specific usage rules, nomenclatures, and recognized file types (e.g., DOIs, CMS locators, etc.) may be defined at application level. The value of this field may also be a hash or checksum.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicating the type of identifier, address, email or other data item.

remarks.p: Generally, this flag is used to relate to schemes and taxonomies defined outside the OSCAL application in some public form; i.e. they can be looked up. The values may be constrained to a locally defined list.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: A value with a name, attributed to the containing control, part, or group.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system. An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated value.

remarks.p: Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, with and among control objects (controls, parts, and extensions), for any purpose useful to an application or implementation of those controls. Typically, properties will be used to sort, select, order, and arrange controls or relate them to one another or to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities.
The value of a property is a simple scalar value or list of values.
The lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure consistency.

Because properties are often used as selectors or identifiers for OSCAL operations, their values can be expected frequently to be normalized (e.g., with respect to whitespace) in use; however, this is application defined.

define-assembly.name: annotation
define-assembly.description: A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.

define-flag.name: value
define-flag.description: Indicates the value of the characteristic.

remarks.p: Annotations permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values for any purpose useful to an application or implementation scenario.
The value (flag) of an annotation is a simple scalar value or list of values. The body of the annotation offers remarks in explanation of or reference to this value.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: Identifying the purpose and intended use of the property, part or other object.

remarks.p: This flag is intended to be used as a control point for validation of properties and parts with respect to constraints related to local semantics. A name is not necessarily expected to be unique, even within the scope of the parent (containing) structure. In some local applications, it is possible for a name to be unique and uniqueness of a name can be validated in such cases.

The definition of a name is subject to its namespace, offered by an ns flag (q.v.). When ns is not given, the namespace is assumed to be oscal and the name should be one of the recognized values for names in OSCAL.

define-flag.name: ns
define-flag.description: A namespace qualifying the name.

remarks.p: Identifies an organization or compliance regime defining the information needs (requirements) addressed by an object. When this attribute is not given, its value should be assumed to be oscal and the name should be a name defined by this specification.

define-flag.name: class
define-flag.description: Indicating the type or classification of the containing object

remarks.p: A class can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over items of a specific class value. Some objects where this flag appears also permit a name and a ns to be assigned, which can provide for more rigor in validation.

define-assembly.name: location
define-assembly.description: A location, with associated metadata that can be referenced.

define-field.name: location-uuid
define-field.description: References a location defined in metadata.

define-assembly.name: party
define-assembly.description: A responsible entity, either singular (an organization or person) or collective (multiple persons)

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: A category describing the kind of party the object describes.

allowed-values.enum: An individual.
A group of individuals formed for a specific purpose.

remarks.p: Parties of both the person or organization type can be associated with an organization using the member-of-organization.

define-field.name: party-uuid
define-field.description: References a party defined in metadata.

define-field.name: external-id
define-field.description: An identifier for a person (such as an ORCID) using a designated scheme.

define-field.name: member-of-organization
define-field.description: Identifies that the containing object is a member of the organization associated with the provided UUID.

define-assembly.name: rlink
define-assembly.description: A pointer to an external copy of a document with optional hash for verification

remarks.p: This is different from unstructured link, which makes no provision for a hash or formal title. It is also different from the element of the same name once proposed for HTML.

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: Describes the type of relationship provided by the link. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.

allowed-values.enum: A link to a homepage related to the containing object.
Interview Notes
Tool Output
Photograph
Questionnaire
Screen Shot

remarks.p: TO DO: discuss IANA link relation registry.

define-flag.name: media-type
define-flag.description: Describes the media type of the linked resource

remarks.p: TO DO: discuss IANA media type registry.

define-field.name: party-name
define-field.description: The full (legal) name of the party.

define-field.name: short-name
define-field.description: A common name, short name or acronym

remarks.p: This element is not expected to be used to identify individual persons, but rather an organization or system.

define-assembly.name: address
define-assembly.description: A postal address.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of address.

allowed-values.enum: A home address.
A work address.

define-field.name: addr-line
define-field.description: A single line of an address.

define-field.name: city
define-field.description: City, town or geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: state
define-field.description: State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: postal-code
define-field.description: Postal or ZIP code for mailing address

define-field.name: country
define-field.description: Country for mailing address

define-field.name: email
define-field.description: Email address

define-field.name: phone
define-field.description: Contact number by telephone

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

allowed-values.enum: A home phone number.
An office phone number.
A mobile phone number.

define-field.name: url
define-field.description: URL for web site or Internet presence

define-field.name: desc
define-field.description: A short textual description

define-field.name: text
define-field.description: A line of textual content whose semantic is determined by the context of use.

define-assembly.name: biblio
define-assembly.description: A container in which a set of bibliographic information can included. The model of this information is undefined by OSCAL.

define-assembly.name: resource
define-assembly.description: A resource associated with the present document, which may be a pointer to other data or a citation.

remarks.p: Use of resource allows for information that pertains to, authenticates, or supplements the document it is included in.

A resource can be used in two ways. 1) it may point to an specific retrievable network resource using a rlink, and 2) be included as an attachment using a base64. A resource may contain multiple rlink and base64 entries that represent alternative download locations (rlink) and attachments (base64) for the same resource. Both rlink and base64 allow for a media-type to be specified, which is used to distiguish between different representations of the same resource (e.g., Microsoft Word, PDF). When multiple rlink and base64 entries are included for a given resource, all entries must contain equivalent information. This is extremely important when the entries represent OSCAL content that is represented in alternate formats (i.e., XML, JSON, YAML). A processor must be able to choose a preferred format to process (based on media-type) with the assumption that the same data can be processed from any of the available formats included by entries.
When a resource is used as a citation, then the title and citation properties must be included.

define-assembly.name: citation
define-assembly.description: A citation consisting of end note text and optional structured bibliographic data.

remarks.p: A text is used to define the endnote text, without any explicit bibliographic structure. If structured bibliographic data is needed, then the biblio> can be used for this purpose.
A biblio can be used to capture a structured bibliograpical citation in an appropriate format.

define-field.name: hash
define-field.description: A representation of a cryptographic digest generated over a resource using a hash algorithm.

remarks.p: A hash value can be used to authenticate that a referenced resource is the same resources as was pointed to by the author of the reference.
When appearing as part of a resource (data object), the hash should apply to the referenced object.

define-flag.name: algorithm
define-flag.description: Method by which a hash is derived

remarks.p: Valid values MUST be a value defined in the W3C XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference Digest Methods (W3C, April 2013).

define-assembly.name: role
define-assembly.description: Defining a role to be assigned to a party

remarks.p: Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

define-flag.name: href
define-flag.description: A link to a document or document fragment (actual, nominal or projected)

remarks.p: Note in particular that href targets include elements (locations) in representations of documents that exist only by virtue of dynamic application, such as (for example) the results of profile resolution.

define-flag.name: id
define-flag.description: Unique identifier of the containing object

remarks.p: No mechanism is proposed to ensure that id values do not collide across different catalogs. Use profiling without merge to detect such clashes.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A RFC 4122 version 4 Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) for the containing object.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A title for display and navigation

remarks.p: A title for the containing object as it should appear in a formatted document.

define-field.name: base64
define-field.description: The Base64 alphabet in RFC 2045 - aligned with XSD.

define-flag.name: filename
define-flag.description: Name of the file before it was encoded as Base64 to be embedded in a resource. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when the file is decoded.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A description supporting the parent item.

define-field.name: remarks
define-field.description: Additional commentary on the parent item.

define-flag.name: component-type
define-flag.description: A category describing the purpose of the component.

allowed-values.enum: Any software, operating system, or firmware
A service that may provide APIs.
A connection to something outside this system.
Any guideline or recommendation
An external assessment performed on some other component, that has been validated by a third-party.

define-flag.name: control-id
define-flag.description: A reference to a control identifier.

define-field.name: system-id
define-field.description: A unique identifier for the system described by this system security plan.

define-flag.name: identifier-type
define-flag.description: Identifies the identification system from which the provided identifier was assigned.

allowed-values.enum: The identifier was assigned by FedRAMP.
A Universally Unique IDentifier (UUID) as defined by RFC4122.

define-assembly.name: component
define-assembly.description: A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: The unique identifier for the component.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the system component.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A description of the component, including information about its function.

define-field.name: purpose
define-field.description: A summary of the technological or business purpose of the component.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: prop field ...

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: The version of the component.
The specific patch level of the component.
The model of the component.
The date the component was released, such as a software release date or policy publication date.
Simple description of the component's function, such as Router, Storage Array, DNS Server.
If a "software" component-type, the identifier, such as a SWID tag, for the software component.
Identifies whether the component is intended to be publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies whether the component is virtualized (yes/no)
Virtual LAN identifier of the component.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the component.
Title of the Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA).
Date of the Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA).
The name of the remote interconnected system.

remarks.p: Some specific property names can be assigned to the component at large, or can be defined when a component is associated with an inventory-item within the implemented-component construct.

define-assembly.name: annotation
define-assembly.description: A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: The name of the baseline configuration for the component.
Can the component be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The physical location of the component's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The function provided by the component for the system.

define-flag.name: value
define-flag.description: Indicates the value of the characteristic.

remarks.p: Some specific annotation names can be assigned to the component at large, or can be defined when a component is associated with an inventory-item within the implemented-component construct.

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: link field ...

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: rel flag ...

allowed-values.enum: A reference to another component that this component has a dependency on.
A reference to another component of type=validation, that is a validation (e.g., FIPS 140-2) for this component
A pointer to a validation record (e.g., FIPS 140-2) or other compliance information.
A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.
This service is used by the referenced component identifier.
This service is provided by the referenced component identifier.
A link to the system interconnection agreement.
A link to the system security plan of the external system.

define-assembly.name: status
define-assembly.description: Describes the operational status of the system.

define-flag.name: state
define-flag.description: XXX

allowed-values.enum: The component is being designed, developed, or implemented.
The component is currently operational and is available for use in the system.
The component is no longer operational.
Some other state.

define-assembly.name: responsible-role
define-assembly.description: A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the control.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: Indicates the role assigned to the responsible party.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Members of the incident response team.
Members of the help desk.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
The organization responsible for the creation and maintenance of the component.
The organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) point of contact (POC) for this system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) point of contact (POC) for the remote interconnected system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) authorizing official for this system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) authorizing official for the remote interconnected system.

remarks.p: The built in roles starting with isa- are used identify the parties that are establishing, authorizing and managing the system interconnection agreement. This allows the authorizing and managing parties on both sides of the interconnection to be defined.
A role defined in this way can be associated with a party or parties here, or where the component is referenced (e.g., inventory-item, implemented-requirement/by-component).

The roles "maintainer" or "provider" can be used to define the supplier. In such cases party-id(s) can be used to associate the providing organization. For products, services, and APIs, this is the vendor and/or retailer information. For policies, processes, plans, standards, and guidance, this is the authoring organization.
Used for service components to define the protocols supported by the service.
Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies, processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security and/or privacy.
The type indicates which of these component types is represented.

When defining a service compoenent where are relationship to other components is known, one or more link entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific component identifer(s) that provide and use the service respectively.

define-assembly.name: protocol
define-assembly.description: Information about the protocol used to provide a service.

remarks.p: The short name of the protocol (e.g., TLS).

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the protocol (e.g., Transport Layer Security).

define-field.name: port-range
define-field.description: Where applicable this is the IPv4 port range on which the service operates.

define-flag.name: start
define-flag.description: Indicates the starting port number in a port range

remarks.p: Should be a number within a permitted range

define-flag.name: end
define-flag.description: Indicates the ending port number in a port range

remarks.p: Should be a number within a permitted range

define-flag.name: transport
define-flag.description: Indicates the transport type.

allowed-values.enum: Transmission Control Protocol
User Datagram Protocol

remarks.p: To be validated as a natural number (integer >= 1). A single port uses the same value for start and end. Use multiple 'port-range' entries for non-contiguous ranges.

define-assembly.name: inventory-item
define-assembly.description: A single managed inventory item within the system.

define-flag.name: asset-id
define-flag.description: Organizational asset identifier that is unique in the context of the system. This may be a reference to the identifier used in an asset tracking system or a vulnerability scanning tool.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: prop field ...

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Identifies whether the asset is publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies whether the asset is virtualized (yes/no)
The Internet Protocol v4 Address of the asset.
The Internet Protocol v6 Address of the asset.
Virtual LAN identifier of the asset.
The network identifier of the asset.
The full-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the asset.
A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for the asset.
A serial number for the asset.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the asset.
The NetBIOS name for the asset.
The media access control (MAC) address for the asset.
The name of the operating system used by the asset.
The version of the operating system used by the asset.
Simple description of the asset's function, such as Router, Storage Array, DNS Server.
The model number of the hardware used by the asset.
The software product name used by the asset.
The software product version used by the asset.
The software product patch level used by the asset.

define-assembly.name: annotation
define-assembly.description: A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: The name of the baseline configuration for the asset.
is the asset subjected to network scans? (yes/no)
Can the asset be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The physical location of the asset's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The function provided by the asset for the system.

define-flag.name: value
define-flag.description: Indicates the value of the characteristic.

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: link field ...

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: rel flag ...

allowed-values.enum: A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.

define-assembly.name: responsible-party
define-assembly.description: A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role relative to the parent context.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: Indicates the role assigned to the responsible party.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Members of the incident response team.
Members of the help desk.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Organization responsible for the creation and maintenance of the component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).

define-assembly.name: implemented-component
define-assembly.description: The set of componenets that are implemented in a given system inventory item.

define-flag.name: component-id
define-flag.description: A reference to a component that is implemented as part of an inventory item.

define-flag.name: use
define-flag.description: The type of implementation

allowed-values.enum: The implemented component is a 'software' component that the inventory item has installed and uses.
The implemented component is a 'hardware' component that the inventory item has installed and uses.
The implemented component is a 'policy' component that the inventory item supports and enforces.
The implemented component is a 'process' component that the inventory item supports and enforces.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: prop field ...

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Identifies whether the asset is publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies whether the asset is virtualized (yes/no)
The Internet Protocol v4 Address of the asset.
The Internet Protocol v6 Address of the asset.
Virtual LAN identifier of the asset.
The network identifier of the asset.
The full-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the asset.
A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for the asset.
A serial number for the asset.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the asset.
The NetBIOS name for the asset.
The media access control (MAC) address for the asset.
Simple description of the asset's function (e.g., Router, Storage Array, DNS Server, etc.).

define-assembly.name: annotation
define-assembly.description: A name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: The name of the baseline configuration for the asset.
is the asset subjected to network scans? (yes/no)
Can the asset be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The physical location of the asset's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The function provided by the asset for the system.

define-flag.name: value
define-flag.description: Indicates the value of the characteristic.

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: link field ...

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: rel flag ...

allowed-values.enum: A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.

define-assembly.name: responsible-party
define-assembly.description: A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role relative to the parent context.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: Indicates the role assigned to the responsible party.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Members of the incident response team.
Members of the help desk.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Organization responsible for the creation and maintenance of the component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).

remarks.p: This construct is used to either: 1) associate a party or parties to a role defined on the component using the responsible-role construct, or 2) to define a party or parties that are responsible for a role defined within the context of the containing inventory-item.

define-assembly.name: import-ssp
define-assembly.description: Used by the assessment plan and POA&M to import information about the system.

define-assembly.name: subject-reference
define-assembly.description: A pointer to a resource based on its ID. Use type to indicate whether the identified resource is a component, inventory item, location, user, or something else.

define-flag.name: uuid-ref
define-flag.description: A pointer to a component, inventory-item, location, party, user, or resource using it's UUID.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: type flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Component
Inventory Item
Location
Interview Party
User
Resource or Artifact

remarks.p: The subject reference UUID could point to an item defined in the SSP, AP, or AR.
Tools should check look for the ID in every file imported directly or indirectly.

define-field.name: compare-to
define-field.description: Typically used in when copying content from the assessment plan to the assessment results. The uuid should be changed in the assessment results file, and the compare-to field should be set to the original assessment plan uuid value. This enables the plan and results to be compared later to identify what changed between the two.

define-assembly.name: schedule
define-assembly.description: Identifies the schedule for the assessment activities.

define-assembly.name: task
define-assembly.description: Identifies an individual task.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: role-id
define-field.description: Identifies roles associated with performing this task.

define-field.name: party-uuid
define-field.description: Identifies people or organizations associated with performing this task.

define-field.name: location-uuid
define-field.description: Identifies locations associated with performing this task.

define-field.name: start
define-field.description: Identifies the start of a task.

define-field.name: end
define-field.description: Identifies the end of a task.

define-field.name: activity-uuid
define-field.description: Links the task to a defined activity.

define-assembly.name: results
define-assembly.description: Used by the assessment results and POA&M. In the assessment results, this identifies all of the assessment observations and findings, initial and residual risks, deviations, and disposition. In the POA&M, this identifies initial and residual risks, deviations, and disposition.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: start
define-field.description: Date/time stamp identifying the start of the evidence collection reflected in these results.

define-field.name: end
define-field.description: Date/time stamp identifying the end of the evidence collection reflected in these results. In a continuous motoring scenario, this may contain the same value as start if appropriate.

define-assembly.name: finding
define-assembly.description: Describes an individual finding.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: For the FedRAMP SAR, must have prop @name='priority' @ns='fedramp', with a numeric value, where '1' is the highest priority.
Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: date-time-stamp
define-field.description: Date/time stamp identifying when the finding information was collected.

define-field.name: party-uuid
define-field.description: The person who collected the evidence or made the observation.

define-field.name: implementation-statement-uuid
define-field.description: Identifies the implementation statement in the SSP to which this finding is related.

define-field.name: date-time-stamp
define-field.description: Date/time stamp identifying when the information was collected.

define-assembly.name: objective-status
define-assembly.description: Captures an assessors conclusions as to whether an objective is fully satisfied.

define-field.name: result
define-field.description: A brief indication as to whether the objective is satisfied or not.

define-field.name: implementation-status
define-field.description: Identifies the implementation status of the control or control objective.

define-flag.name: system
define-flag.description: Identifies the framework or rules to which this value conforms.

allowed-values.enum: The value conforms to FedRAMP definitions.
A value conforms to NIST definitions.

define-assembly.name: observation
define-assembly.description: Describes an individual observation.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.
Identifies who was interviewed, or what was tested or inspected.

define-field.name: origin
define-field.description: Identifies the source of the finding, such as a tool, interviewed person, or activity.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: type flag ...

allowed-values.enum: An assessment tool, defined in the assets section of the assessment plan or results.
A test method defined in the assessment-activities section of the assessment plan or results.
A task defined in the schedule of the assessment plan or results.
An assessment activity defined in the assessment-activities section of the assessment plan or results.
The UUID points elsewhere in the this file or an imported file.

define-assembly.name: relevant-evidence
define-assembly.description: Links this observation to relevant evidence.

remarks.p: Links to evidence as URI. May use a URI fragment to point to a resource in the back-matter.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: assessor
define-field.description: Identifies an individual who gathered the evidence resulting in the observation or risk identification.

define-flag.name: party-uuid
define-flag.description: The UUID of the assessor who collected the evidence or made the observation.

define-flag.name: uuid-ref
define-flag.description: A pointer to a relevant item, using it's UUID.

define-field.name: observation-method
define-field.description: Identifies how the observation was made.

allowed-values.enum: An inspection was performed.
An interview was performed.
A manual or automated test was performed.
A manual test was performed.
An automated test was performed.
Only use for historic conversion of old assessment observations that may include a mix of methods.

define-field.name: observation-type
define-field.description: Identifies the nature of the observation. More than one may be used to further qualify and enable filtering.

allowed-values.enum: A difference between the SSP implementation statement, and actual implementation.
An observation about the status of a the associated control objective.
A mitigating factor was identified.
An assessment finding. Used for observations made by tools, penetration testing, and other means.
An observation from a past assessment, which was converted to OSCAL at a later date.

define-field.name: threat-id
define-field.description: A pointer, by ID, to an externally-defined threat.

define-flag.name: system
define-flag.description: Specifies the source of the threat information.

allowed-values.enum: The value conforms to FedRAMP definitions.

define-flag.name: uri
define-flag.description: An optional location for the threat data, from which this ID originates.

define-assembly.name: risk
define-assembly.description: An identified risk.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.
For the FedRAMP SAR, must have prop @name='risk-reduction-auto-approve' @ns='fedramp', with a value of "yes" or "no". If missing, or no value, the default is "no".

define-field.name: risk-metric
define-field.description: An individual risk metric from a specified system.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: name flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Impacted Control
Vulnerability ID
Source ID
Likelihood
Impact
Risk
Access Vector
Access Complexity
Authentication
Confidentiality Impact
Integrity Impact
Availability Impact
Remediation Level
Report Confidence
Collateral Damage Potential
Target Distribution
Confidentiality Requirement
Integrity Requirement
Availability Requirement
Privileges Required
User Interaction
Scope
Exploit Maturity
Modified Attack Vector
Modified Attack Complexity
Modified Privileges Required
Modified User Interaction
Modified Scope
Modified Confidentiality
Modified Integrity
Modified Availability
Access Vector
Access Complexity
Authentication
Confidentiality Impact
Integrity Impact
Availability Impact
Exploitability
Remediation Level
Report Confidence
Collateral Damage Potential
Target Distribution
Confidentiality Requirement
Integrity Requirement
Availability Requirement
Privileges Required
User Interaction
Scope
Exploit Code Maturity
Modified Attack Vector
Modified Attack Complexity
Modified Privileges Required
Modified User Interaction
Modified Scope
Modified Confidentiality
Modified Integrity
Modified Availability

define-flag.name: class
define-flag.description: class flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Initial
Residual

define-flag.name: system
define-flag.description: Specifies the system represented by this risk metric.

define-assembly.name: remediation-tracking
define-assembly.description: A log of events and actions taken towards the remediation of the associated risk.

define-assembly.name: tracking-entry
define-assembly.description: Individual remediation tracking entry, which logs an event or action taken towards the remediation of the associated risk.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: type flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Vendor Check-In
Status Update
Milestone Complete
Mitigation Implemented
Risk is Remediated
Closed
Deviation Request Submission
Deviation Requested Updated
Deviation Request Approved
Deviation Request Rejected

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-assembly.name: required
define-assembly.description: Identifies something required to achieve remediation.

remarks.p: Identifies a subject associated with this requirement, such as a party, system component, or inventory-item.

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: risk-status
define-field.description: Describes the status of the associated risk.

allowed-values.enum: Open
Closed

define-field.name: closure-actions
define-field.description: Describes the actions taken that resulted in the closure of the identified risk.

define-assembly.name: mitigating-factor
define-assembly.description: Describes a mitigating factor with an optional link to an implementation statement in the SSP.

remarks.p: Links identifiable elements of the system to this mitigating factor, such as an inventory-item or component.

define-assembly.name: remediation
define-assembly.description: Describes either recommendation or an actual plan for remediating the risk.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: type flag ...

allowed-values.enum: Recommended Remediation
Planned Remediation

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

remarks.p: Provided as means of extending the OSCAL syntax.

define-field.name: remediation-origin
define-field.description: Points to the source of the recommendation

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: type flag ...

allowed-values.enum: The UUID of the person or organization who made the recommendation
The UUID of the tool that made the recommendation

define-field.name: risk-statement
define-field.description: Describes the risk.

define-flag.name: implementation-uuid
define-flag.description: Points to an implementation statement in the SSP.

define-flag.name: objective-id
define-flag.description: Points to an assessment objective.

define-assembly.name: plan-of-action-and-milestones
define-assembly.description: A plan of action and milestones, such as those required by FedRAMP.

remarks.p: Used by the POA&M to import information about the system.
Either an OSCAL-based SSP must be imported, or a unique system-id must be specified. Both may be present.

define-assembly.name: local-definitions
define-assembly.description: Allows components, and inventory-items to be defined within the POA&M for circumstances where no OSCAL-based SSP exists, or is not delivered with the POA&M.

remarks.p: Used to add any components, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR->AP->SSP)
Used to add any inventory-items, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR->AP->SSP)
